title.narrative: Støtte til UNDP 2017: Immediate Assistance to the Libyan Political Dialogue and Government of National Accord

description.narrative: .Støtte til UNDP 2017: Immediate Assistance to the Libyan Political Dialogue and Government of National Accord

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

policy-marker.narrative: Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

title.narrative: Output 1, Activity 1.2 UNSMIL is able to convene dialogue meetings in maintenance of the political agreement and in support to the GNA

actual.value: In 2018, UNSMIL and UNDP-facilitated dialogue sessions, which proved to be instrumental in creating a conducive environment for productive dialogues among various stakeholder groups. Moreover, they indicated a major political breakthrough as the majority of those invited to participate endorsed the Libyan Political Agreement (LPA). A primary objective of the dialogue process was the adoption of the LPA, the formation of the GNA, and proper implementation of the LPA in order to allow for the eventual end of the political transition in Libya. The main activities conducted in 2018 under the project were a “South Day Event”, a Constitution Expert Meeting and a Media Mapping Survey. Due to the dynamic situation, UNSMIL and UNDP experienced delays in the political reconciliation process during 2018.

In February 2020, after two rounds of talks in Geneva, the 5+5 Joint Military Commission completed a draft ceasefire agreement, which in March was under review by the leaderships of the GNA and Libyan National Army (LNA). Despite obstruction from the leaderships of the High Council of State (HCS) and the House of Representatives (HOR), in its first meetings from 24-27 February, the LPDF from 24-27 February formulated a draft agenda and terms of reference for the political process. On the 10 June 2020, both Government of National Accord (GNA) and The Libyan National Army (LNA) delegations, were fully engaged in the third round of talks of the (5+5) Joint Military Commission (JMC). The Mission convened a meeting with the LNA delegation on 03 June and another meeting with the GNA delegation on, 09 June. The meeting was conducted virtually and were productive that discussed the delegation latest development on the ground and received their comments on the draft ceasefire agreement.

The project was organizing a national conference in April 2019 designed to bring together representatives of Libyan constituencies and agree on steps necessary to end the transition. Due to escalation of conflict initiated by forces of Libyan National Army seizing control of Tripoli, UNSMIL removed all non-essential staff from Libya and the Conference was postponed.
In the aftermath of the postponement of the National Conference, UNSMIL and UNDP organized two consultation meetings in May and June 2019 with a number of the original invitees to hear from the stakeholders their views on what Libyan political engagement was possible to support UNSMIL’s efforts to end to the current conflict. Participants included revolutionaries, supporters of the former regime, Islamists, the National Alliance, the business sector, NGOs, women and youth. They proposed a number of solutions including a way to address distribution of wealth. These meetings were funded under the Danish contribution.

title.narrative:
Outcome 2: Central and local government authorities are strengthened to provide better public services to citizens.
(Danish contribution only covers outcome 2, output 1)
Output 1. Safe and neutral platform provided within the framework of the political dialogue, helping to foster confidence building between actors and relevant stakeholders
Activity 1.1: UNSMIL is able to convene all tracks of the dialogue process towards endorsement of the political agreement in a timely and inclusive manner

actual.value: The Libyan Political Dialogue Forum was convened by UNSMIL that commenced in Geneva on the 26th February 2020. The Political talks went ahead despite the last-minute pull-out by both the Tobruk-based House of Representatives (HOR) and the Tripoli-based High Council of State (HCS). The invitees for the talks are 50 delegates – 13 from the House of Representatives, 13 from the High Council of State, 14 independents selected by UNSMIL plus 10 women selected by UNSMIL. The Tripoli-based High Council of State said it will not take part until there is a progress in the 5+5 Joint Military Commission (JMC) negotiations, the second round of which ended in Geneva on 23 February. It also demanded to know in advance the agenda of the meeting and the names of participants from the House of Representatives. Also, the Tobruk-based House of Representatives wants to see the agenda in advance.

UNSMIL facilitated dialogues through a number of distinct tracks: the main ('political') track (track 1). These negotiations, while necessary, were not sufficient. Therefore, a number of ancillary, foundational preparatory dialogues were conducted with security actors, tribal leaders, political parties, municipal officials, women leaders and civil society.

Under activity 1.1. UNSMIL facilitated dialogues through a number of distinct tracks: the main ('political') track; security; tribal leaders; political parties; municipalities; women; and civil society. Each track met separately under UNSMIL's facilitation and fed into the overall process: UNSMIL facilitated meetings, and parallel good offices interventions, for each track of the dialogue process. The primary objective of the main track of the dialogue was the development and endorsement of a political agreement between various groups within Libya. The political agreement was meant to address the definition and formation of the Government of the Government of National Accord (GNA)
